body: Also, I'd love something like CoffeeScript's multi-line string support, which normalizes the indentation, removing a lot of unnecessary spaces.

issue.title: Multi-Line Strings include the trailing slash

repository.name: jade4j
repository.description: a pug implementation written in Java (formerly known as jade)

issue.body:
First off, I'm not sure that Jade itself supports multi-line strings by intention: https://github.com/visionmedia/jade/issues/1447 But assuming it does, Jade4J messs up slightly: ``` div(attr="foo \ bar \ baz") ``` compiles to ```
``` ... that is, the slashes are being included.

body: Oh, this useful. Thanks for posting about it. (+1)
It's only useful if the Jade maintainers agree that it's a supported feature!

I'm surprised that exists, didn't know about it myself (which is part of the reason it's not documented). 

There are a few issues I potentially have with it:
1. It leads to extra white space if you aren't careful.  The example you gave actually puts 3 spaces between each value.
2. It seems like it will be somewhat redundant once we have support for ES6 multi-line strings (admittedly a long way down the line) as you could just do:
   
   ``` jade
   div(attr=`foo
     bar
     baz`)
   ```
   
   which will work without any special jade syntax (in the future).
3. It seems kind of odd that the result of a multi-line jade attribute is a single line html attribute.

I'm fairly happy to go either way.  The options are:
1. Document it and support it for the foreseeable future.
2. Deprecate it with a warning and then remove it in 2.0.0 (probably still at least a few months away)

+1 for option 2.

I don't think the extra whitespace would count as "expected" behavior, so it's not really a great solution to the problem (at least not great enough to make it a supported feature).

Please keep it, or if you want to kill it, replace it with something like template strings (maybe just backticks for now, or untagged ones). We used this extensively on one project in order to keep our lines under 120 characters while still using libraries like Knockout.js that expect a whole microsyntax to be encoded into an attribute.
@domenic Can I ask why you need to keep the lines under 120 characters?

And I think it's reasonable to keep lines relatively short myself ... just cause you can scroll doesn't mean you want to have to (especially if you have to do a merge at some point).  That was my reason for wanting sanctioned multi-line attribute values myself ... more shorter lines.
Aren't the strings simply JavaScript strings and therefore allow to escape newlines just like JavaScript?

@lydell yes, if you want literal newlines in the output you should just use `\n` in your jade file.  The argument for this feature is that it helps you keep your code looking tidy by keeping the line lengths shorter.

@domenic that's a pretty good point, I guess knockout bindings could lead to some very long lines.  I'm leaning towards documenting it and supporting it.

Sorry, I was a bit unclear. I just tried to explain a theory on why it is not documented.

Following the equals sign in a attributevalue pair is a JavaScript expression. Always. One very common JavaScript expression is a string. The source code of a JavaScript string cannot contain newline characters, unless you escape them with a backslash. However, escaped newlines are ignored; they do not alter the content of the string. It simply allows you to continue the source code of the string on a new line.

Knowing that I'm simply writing a JavaScript expression and nothing Jade-specific, the feature is totally expected without being documented. Still, since it is useful, a bit of documentation doesn't hurt.
Ah, that solves it.  I'd forgotten that was a feature of JavaScript.  In that case we should definitely document and keep.  I'll add a note to the new documentation site I'm working on.

I second what @domenic said in regards to Knockout.js, and also for inline style attributes, or click handlers (don't you judge me!)

I'd prefer backticks to the current backslash syntax.

issue.title: newlines in attribute values

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug  robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
sometimes the values of my attributes get very long, especially with angular ng-class attributes.
It would be really nice to allow newlines within attribute values (until you get to the closing ")

like this:

``` jade
div(ng-class="{
  success: myCtrl.everythingWorked(),
  calamity: myCtrl.whatsUp()
}") that's what you get and you don't throw a fit.
```

this answer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14928536/can-the-html-class-element-attribute-contain-line-breaks
seems to indicate newlines in there should be valid for html.

this might be slightly related to #868

body: Is there any problem with just extending the grammar to support multiline strings in single quotes directly?

@DavidSouther Yes, I really want to avoid supporting anything that isn't part of JavaScript inside those strings. We should be able to support template literals pretty soon, which allows you to have multi line strings delimited by `
Could it be extended with something like `\-` to remove the whitespace? Or get to the template literals soon?
